title: Nafi Thiam exclusive interview: 'People take pictures when I'm doing my shopping - that's not very cool'
text:
The Naimette-Xhovement track in Liege is all but deserted when Nafi Thiam arrives on a balmy September afternoon. Athletics tracks tend to be quiet places at this time of year and, while almost everyone in her training group has already ended their season, the late World Championships in Doha mean she must keep plugging away for a few weeks longer.

The absence of her training partners should have little impact, though. As the sole athlete of world-class standard in the group, Thiam does much of her training alone anyway – certainly when it comes to running, where the men tend to be too quick and the women too slow.

Aside from Thiam, the Olympic, world and European heptathlon champion, the only other senior international is one whose most notable achievement is representing Luxembourg at the Games of the Small States of Europe. It is quite a gulf.

A toddler who has been unsteadily running up and down the home straight takes an inevitable tumble and starts crying; Thiam, 25, offers a friendly greeting to one of the elderly volunteer coaches; the sun continues to shine; everything is relaxed.

This has been Thiam’s home track ever since she began making the routine hour-long train journey after school from her mother’s house in Namur to Liege and back when she was 14. Four days a week she would complete her schoolwork on the train home before arriving to her dinner plate left on the table. “If you want something, you have to work or it’s not going to happen,” she says of the arduous schedule.

The signs of future success were always there. Her sinewy 6ft 2in physique lends itself to the heptathlon and after climbing the junior ranks with a smattering of medals, her star now shines far beyond small Belgian towns.

Nafi Thiam looks close to unbeatable in the heptathlon Credit: Paul Grover More

It is difficult to know what is most impressive: the global titles, the unbeaten streak dating back to May 2016, or the fact that only two women – Jackie Joyner-Kersee and Carolina Kluft – have points tallies in history higher than her.

As much as Britain’s Katarina Johnson-Thompson is improving each year, there remains an enormous 200 points between their respective personal bests. That Johnson-Thompson is expected to win world silver in Doha next week shows just how far ahead Thiam really is.

With each year and every accomplishment, her fame grows bigger in Belgium. There is a giant poster of Thiam’s face at the entrance to her home track and she was given headline status at the Brussels Diamond League earlier this month, leading a procession of international athletes driven round the track in open-top cars. It is a crown that sits uncomfortably on someone who describes themselves as naturally shy.

“If I’m in an environment I don’t know, with people I don’t know, I’ll just observe. That’s just the way I am,” she says, in flawless English. “But you get used to things. You just learn to do the job – it’s part of it. There are still some things I don’t really like. But that’s like everything, you have good sides and bad sides.

“As long as it’s in the athletics circle I’m comfortable with it. It’s when it goes to the personal side that it’s maybe sometimes a bit uncomfortable.

“When I do my groceries or I’m at a restaurant and people take pictures that isn’t very cool because you don’t feel very comfortable and feel like people are watching you. I don’t think I’ll ever get used to that. But most people are really nice and supportive. I still have a normal life and I don’t have to hide or anything. I wouldn’t like it to get bigger. A little celebrity is enough.”
